column2: officially the City of Oroquieta (Cebuano: Dakbayan sa Oroquieta; Tagalog: Lungsod ng Oroquieta)
column3: is a 4th class city and capital of the province of Misamis Occidental

column1: Some sources reveal that the town got its name from the barrio in Spain where Father Toas Tomas Casado
column3: and General Domingo Moriones y Murillo
column4: a hero in the Battle of Oroquieta
column5: were born.Another version is that Oroquieta had derived its name from the words oro (gold) and quita or kita (to find)
column6: in reference to the early inhabitants who had found gold along the river.

column1: Layawan was the original name of Oroquieta
column2: which was the barrio in the province of Misamis since 1861 until 1879. The early settlers then of the barrio were Boholanos. They found so many stray animals along the river
column3: thus they named the place Layawan
column4: which means a place of stray animals. A little later
column5: Misamis was divided into two provinces
column6: Misamis Occidental and Oriental. Then in 1880
column7: Layawan changed its name to Oroquieta when it became a town.

column1: Oroquieta became the capital (cabecera) on January 6
column3: people of various neighboring provinces came and inhabited in the place where they earn their living through fishing
column5: merchandising and other forms of businesses. Soon afterwards its income increased simultaneously with increase in population.

column2: Oroquieta was made the capital of the free Philippines by the recognized guerrillas and later the ongoing troops of the Philippine Commonwealth Army. (Personal interview with the late Atty. Vicente Blanco
column3: Municipal Mayor during the Japanese Occupation) During this time
column6: a bodyguard and Major Manuel Nieto Sr.
column7: landed in Oroquieta after their evacuation from Corregidor to Australia.

column1: The seat of government of the Free Philippines then was the Capitol. The Free Philippine Government was then issuing Misamis Occidental emergency notes. President Quezon
column2: upon knowing that Oroquieta was made a capital of the Free Philippines and that the town was issuing emergency notes
column3: authorized the Printing of the Mindanao emergency note.

column1: Oroquieta was created a city under Republic Act 5518 and inaugurated as a chartered city on January 1
column2: 1970. The charter converting the municipality of Oroquieta into a city were signed by President Marcos on June 25
column4: in the presence of the then City Mayor Ciriaco C. Pastrano
column5: with the newly elected councilors and other city officials.

column1: Oroquieta City is bounded on the south by Aloran and the north by Lopez Jaena. On the eastern side is Iligan Bay
column2: with Concepcion on the southwest and Sapang Dalaga on the northwest. Lowland plains and coastal lowlands are located in the city's eastern side while highlands and mountains tower over its western side.

column4: the majority of which comprises the mountain barangays of Mialen

column8: the 47 barangays of the City outsize its urbanized counterparts.

column1: Oroquieta City is politically subdivided into 47 barangays. Population 2015 census.
